title: Tech Down on Rotation Out of Growth, Into Value — Tech Roundup
text:
The technology sector fell as traders rotated out of "growth" stocks, which typically trade at a premium compared with earnings and into "value" stocks, which are considered cheap.

After years of outperformance, large-cap growth stocks, many of which are Silicon Valley companies, have started to lag the performance of value stocks in recent sessions, The Wall Street Journal reported.

"Buying the winners and selling the losers has worked really well since the middle of February but we think performance has been too good," said strategist at brokerage Jefferies, in a note to clients. "Thus, we think rotating back to valuations mattering makes sense and we have started to see this happen here in September."

Apple shares rose after the tech hardware maker kicked off its annual product showcase with a preview of a new TV service that will cost $4.99 a month and be free for a year to anyone who buys a new iPhone, iPad or Mac. Apple also launched a new iPhone, the iPhone 11, which it said will have a faster processor and improved cameras.

Ride-hailing giant Uber Technologies said it cut 435 technical employees, the latest in a series of layoffs as it faces market pressures to turn a profit.

Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 10, 2019 17:26 ET (21:26 GMT)
